title: Creating Phantom/Ghost Transfer
text: By Thomas T In some instances where an IBT is missing data or you simply want to record a transfer in from a store that doesn't exist in RMS it may be required to create a phantom transfer (transfer with one blank destination) to amend the stock and keep a record of the transfer for reporting on in the future. In Store Operations Manager, navigate to Inventory > Transfer Inventory In and create a new Inventory Transfer. Follow the Wizard to add the required items to the transfer list: (Optional) Enter a title for the Inventory Transfer that ties it to the original Transfer that didn’t complete correctly for easier reporting: (IMPORTANT) Leave the “Transfer from” field blank. Ensure “Transfer Type” is set to Standard. Enter the required quantities (and items if you chose to raise a blank transfer for manual entry) in the ‘contents’ tab: Hit “Ok”. If the Order number has been left blank, you’ll receive a prompt asking if you wish to automatically generate one. Click ‘Yes’. Alternatively, you may wish to use the transfer number to tie into the original transfer too. The transfer has now been raised. Once you’re ready to receive it in, select it from the list and click “Receive”. Enter the quantities in the “Qty Rcv” field or simply hit the “Receive all” button and then commit: Click yes to the following two prompts to place the order and commit the quantities to the database: Press “Ok” on the transfer screen and the phantom transfer will be completed.
description:
By Thomas T

In some instances where an IBT is missing data or you simply want to record a transfer in from a store that doesn't exist in RMS it may be required to create a phantom transfer (transfer with one blank destination) to amend the stock and keep a record of the transfer for reporting on in the future.

    1. In Store Operations Manager, navigate to Inventory > Transfer Inventory In and create a new Inventory Transfer.

 

    1. Follow the Wizard to add the required items to the transfer list: 

 

 

    1. (Optional) Enter a title for the Inventory Transfer that ties it to the original Transfer that didn’t complete correctly for easier reporting:

 

 

    1. (IMPORTANT) Leave the “Transfer from” field blank.

 

    1. Ensure “Transfer Type” is set to Standard.

 

    1. Enter the required quantities (and items if you chose to raise a blank transfer for manual entry) in the ‘contents’ tab:

 

    1. Hit “Ok”. If the Order number has been left blank, you’ll receive a prompt asking if you wish to automatically generate one. Click ‘Yes’. 

      1. Alternatively, you may wish to use the transfer number to tie into the original transfer too.

 

 

    1. The transfer has now been raised. Once you’re ready to receive it in, select it from the list and click “Receive”.

 

 

    1. Enter the quantities in the “Qty Rcv” field or simply hit the “Receive all” button and then commit:

 

    1. Click yes to the following two prompts to place the order and commit the quantities to the database:

 

 

    1. Press “Ok” on the transfer screen and the phantom transfer will be completed.

title: Closing a Store Checklist
text: By - Matt Shepheard Closing a single store Local Customers – Check local customers do not have any outstanding payments due. Use the Local Customer List in HQ Manager - Reports to see Balances due. Either pay off balances or convert customer to a global customer. Sales and polling - Complete a final Z read on all slave tills (on PoS and C&P). No further sales should be put through on these tills. Ensure the master till has been Z-read. No further sales should be put through. Poll HQ Client ensuring a 401 is processed. After last sales are complete it is advisable to take a stock value report (quantities and £). Stock - All stock must be removed from the closing store before last poll otherwise it will always remain as stock in HQ. This can be done by transferring all stock to another store as an IBT before the last poll. Alternatively stocktake all items down to 0 and then reallocate the stock separately. Database - Ensure a backup of the database is make and kept somewhere safe and take all the data from it that is needed. Consider restoring it somewhere for historical data purposes but make sure it cannot poll back to HQ (see below). Inactive store – Depending on version of RMS mark the store as inactive in HQ Manager. Once marked as inactive on the next 401 all data transfer between the stores will cease. From HQ Manager after the last poll stop sending the store worksheets. If the store cannot be made inactive consider renaming the store to ‘Store Name – CLOSED’ or similar as a reminder. The last 401 will sit in the system against the store but after you stop the branch polling this final 401 will never get processed. HQ Client – Disable HQ Client application by removing registry key for licence or remove all the settings from File – Configuration in the HQ Client software. Consider uninstalling this software too, to prevent it from being activated again accidentally/unintentionally i.e. the PC is being reused at another store.
description:
By - Matt Shepheard

Closing a single store

Local Customers –

Check local customers do not have any outstanding payments due. Use the Local Customer List in HQ Manager - Reports to see Balances due. Either pay off balances or convert customer to a global customer.

Sales and polling -

Complete a final Z read on all slave tills (on PoS and C&P). No further sales should be put through on these tills.

Ensure the master till has been Z-read. No further sales should be put through.

Poll HQ Client ensuring a 401 is processed.

After last sales are complete it is advisable to take a stock value report (quantities and £).

Stock -

All stock must be removed from the closing store before last poll otherwise it will always remain as stock in HQ.

This can be done by transferring all stock to another store as an IBT before the last poll. Alternatively stocktake all items down to 0 and then reallocate the stock separately. 

Database -

Ensure a backup of the database is make and kept somewhere safe and take all the data from it that is needed. Consider restoring it somewhere for historical data purposes but make sure it cannot poll back to HQ (see below).

Inactive store –

Depending on version of RMS mark the store as inactive in HQ Manager. Once marked as inactive on the next 401 all data transfer between the stores will cease. 

From HQ Manager after the last poll stop sending the store worksheets. If the store cannot be made inactive consider renaming the store to ‘Store Name – CLOSED’ or similar as a reminder.

The last 401 will sit in the system against the store but after you stop the branch polling this final 401 will never get processed.

HQ Client –

Disable HQ Client application by removing registry key for licence or remove all the settings from File – Configuration in the HQ Client software. Consider uninstalling this software too, to prevent it from being activated again accidentally/unintentionally i.e. the PC is being reused at another store.

title: Creating Discount Macros
text: (By - Abbie Lawton) Log into the POS and make sure there are no current Discounts or Sale affecting statuses already applied. Press CTRL + F3 start to record the macro this will bring up the Record Macro box, name the macro accordingly as this will be what the button shows up as on the POS. Once finished press OK. After pressing OK a red flashing indicator will appear on the status screen, this indicates that the Macro (and therefore any button presses) are now being recorded. With the possibility of buttons on the Point of Sale being moved it is always better to key in the commands instead of clicking them. To get to the discount press menu press SHIFT + F3. The Discount menu will then appear, however it is of note that the macro will freeze the recording as a new menu has come up. To get around this press CTRL + F3, after that press and hold the Shift key for a short while to start the Macro recording again. This will change the Macro indicator back onto the flashing red for recording. Once on the Set Discount/ Price Level Screen with the macro again recording, the desired amount must be enter using keys again instead of clicking. To do this there are underlined letters in the sentences for the options available. To get to these without clicking Press the ALT + the underlined letter required. For example using the image above as an guide, if it was required to Set the discount method for transaction and then Discount from retail price for an amount of 20% the key commands would be: ALT +S ALT + D ALT + T Key in 20% Tab and then Space to enter If reason codes have been set up for discounts the user will be required to enter a reason for the discount. Type in the Code in the search which should already be in the right area and then enter. With the steps finished press CTRL + F3 which will give the use the ‘Macro Recorded Successfully’ message To apply and test the macro Log into Store Operations Manager > Database > Registers > Keyboards, select the Keyboard that is currently in use for the POS and press Properties. Once done this will bring up the Touchscreen Keyboard Properties which will show the Touch buttons currently set up. Use Add to begin adding the previously made Macro. As shown below, choose the Style as the Function Key and open the Function dropdown and select the appropriate macro. For example if it is the first macro that has been made it will be Macro 1. The Caption can be given to remind the user what the macro is. Once finished press Ok to the Keyboard Key Properties window and Ok Touchscreen Keyboard Properties Window. Exit the POS once finished and then re-launch the POS. Using the Next and Previous buttons navigate to the newly created Macro Button and press it to see if it works as expected
description:
(By - Abbie Lawton)

Log into the POS and make sure there are no current Discounts or Sale affecting statuses already applied. 

    1. Press CTRL + F3 start to record the macro this will bring up the Record Macro box, name the macro accordingly as this will be what the button shows up as on the POS. Once finished press OK.         

 

    1. After pressing OK a red flashing indicator will appear on the status screen, this indicates that the Macro (and therefore any button presses) are now being recorded. 

 

 

 

    1. With the possibility of buttons on the Point of Sale being moved it is always better to key in the commands instead of clicking them. To get to the discount press menu press SHIFT + F3. 
    2. The Discount menu will then appear, however it is of note that the macro will freeze the recording as a new menu has come up.

 

 

 

 

    1. To get around this press CTRL + F3, after that press and hold the Shift key for a short while to start the Macro recording again. This will change the Macro indicator back onto the flashing red for recording. 

 

    1. Once on the Set Discount/ Price Level Screen with the macro again recording, the desired amount must be enter using keys again instead of clicking.

 

    1. To do this there are underlined letters in the sentences for the options available. To get to these without clicking Press the ALT + the underlined letter required. 
    2. For example using the image above as an guide, if it was required to Set the discount method for transaction and then Discount from retail price for an amount of 20% the key commands would be: 

    1. ALT +S
    2. ALT +  D 
    3. ALT + T
    4. Key in 20%
    5. Tab and then Space to enter

    1. If reason codes have been set up for discounts the user will be required to enter a reason for the discount.         Type in the Code in the search which should already be in the right area and then enter. 
    2. With the steps finished press CTRL +  F3 which will give the use the ‘Macro Recorded Successfully’ message
    3. To apply and test the macro Log into Store Operations Manager > Database > Registers > Keyboards, select the Keyboard that is currently in use for the POS and press Properties. 
    4. Once done this will bring up the Touchscreen Keyboard Properties which will show the Touch buttons currently set up. Use Add to begin adding the previously made Macro.  
    5. As shown below, choose the Style as the Function Key and open the Function dropdown and select the appropriate macro. For example if it is the first macro that has been made it will be Macro 1. The Caption can be given to remind the user what the macro is.         

 

    1. Once finished press Ok to the Keyboard Key Properties window and Ok Touchscreen Keyboard Properties Window. 
    2. Exit the POS once finished and then re-launch the POS. Using the Next and Previous buttons navigate to the newly created Macro Button and press it to see if it works as expected

title: Failed 401 Worksheets
text: by Abbie Lawton If a customer has logged a case regarding that they are either missing transfers or the HQ hasn’t received sales from a store, it would be that the site is no longer polling 401 worksheets. Remote onto the server machine or a machine that has HQ Manager installed. Log into HQ Manager and open Worksheet status. If there is a red flag showing on a Data Upload (401 worksheet) double click on it to open it up. Take note of the reference number and click the 'Acknowledge' button. This will then change the red flag to a grey flag. Then click on admin, then worksheets, then search the reference number. Highlight the worksheet and click the 'Copy' button on the right side. Once the new worksheet opens click the 'Approve' button on the left side. When the store HQ client polls all transactions and transfers should then upload to HQ.
description:
by Abbie Lawton

If a customer has logged a case regarding that they are either missing transfers or the HQ hasn’t received sales from a store, it would be that the site is no longer polling 401 worksheets.

Remote onto the server machine or a machine that has HQ Manager installed. Log into HQ Manager and open Worksheet status.

 

If there is a red flag showing on a Data Upload (401 worksheet) double click on it to open it up.

Take note of the reference number and click the 'Acknowledge' button. This will then change the red flag to a grey flag.

Then click on admin, then worksheets, then search the reference number.

 

Highlight the worksheet and click the 'Copy' button on the right side. Once the new worksheet opens click the 'Approve' button on the left side.

When the store HQ client polls all transactions and transfers should then upload to HQ.

title: HQ Client Not Connecting to HQ Server
text: by Abbie Lawton When a customer logs a case regarding HQ client and HQ server, first remote onto the till. Check that HQ client is open on the till. Next remote onto the server machine or the machine that has HQ server installed which could be a Backoffice machine. Make sure that HQ server is started. In most cases, the server machine will have restarted and HQ server and Voucher server will need to be started after logging into windows. After making sure HQ server is opened check that HQ client is now able to poll. You can force poll by clicking the connect button. If it's now connecting fine there isn't anything further you need to do. Sometimes HQ client might be connecting but the customer has explained the issue as it not connecting. They could mean that HQ client hasn’t been polling 401 worksheets and HQ hasn’t received their sales. If this is the case please see the Failed 401 worksheets page. If HQ server is started but HQ client is still unable to connect it might be that the IP address has changed on the server machine.
description:
by Abbie Lawton


When a customer logs a case regarding HQ client and HQ server, first remote onto the till. Check that HQ client is open on the till. 

 

Next remote onto the server machine or the machine that has HQ server installed which could be a Backoffice machine. Make sure that HQ server is started. In most cases, the server machine will have restarted and HQ server and Voucher server will need to be started after logging into windows.

 

After making sure HQ server is opened check that HQ client is now able to poll. You can force poll by clicking the connect button. If it's now connecting fine there isn't anything further you need to do. 

 

Sometimes HQ client might be connecting but the customer has explained the issue as it not connecting. They could mean that HQ client hasn’t been polling 401 worksheets and HQ hasn’t received their sales. If this is the case please see the Failed 401 worksheets page.

 

If HQ server is started but HQ client is still unable to connect it might be that the IP address has changed on the server machine.

title: Missing Transfers
text: By Abbie Lawton When the customer logs a case for missing transfers, key information you should get from them is the transfer numbers, the sending store, and the receiving store. To start remote onto the customers server machine or a machine that has HQ Manager installed. Log into HQ manager and open Worksheet status. Make sure that there are no failed Data Uploads (401 worksheet) for both the sending and receiving store. This will be shown as a red flag. If they are all green, you can move on. Now go into Inventory Transfer status. One opened select the From Transfer # from the field options and type in the transfer number in the Filter value then click on add. Then click OK. This will run a report and bring up the transfer with that number. If nothing shows up when you run this report its likely that the transfer hasn’t been received at HQ yet. What you’re most likely going to see that in the To Transfer# column is empty but the transfer is showing the report. On most of our customer servers you will see a program called ReSend Transfers. Run this program and you should see this window. Type in the transfer number in the Filter by Transfer no: and click Refresh. When the transfer shows underneath click on it to highlight it blue and click Re-Send Selected Transfers. Once the receiving store polls the next data upload (401 worksheet) the transfer should then show at the store.
description:
By Abbie Lawton

When the customer logs a case for missing transfers, key information you should get from them is the transfer numbers, the sending store, and the receiving store.

To start remote onto the customers server machine or a machine that has HQ Manager installed. Log into HQ manager and open Worksheet status.

 

Make sure that there are no failed Data Uploads (401 worksheet) for both the sending and receiving store. This will be shown as a red flag. If they are all green, you can move on.

Now go into Inventory Transfer status.

One opened select the From Transfer # from the field options and type in the transfer number in the Filter value then click on add. 

 

Then click OK. This will run a report and bring up the transfer with that number.

If nothing shows up when you run this report its likely that the transfer hasn’t been received at HQ yet. What you’re most likely going to see that in the To Transfer# column is empty but the transfer is showing the report.

On most of our customer servers you will see a program called ReSend Transfers.

Run this program and you should see this window.

Type in the transfer number in the Filter by Transfer no: and click Refresh.

When the transfer shows underneath click on it to highlight it blue and click Re-Send Selected Transfers.

Once the receiving store polls the next data upload (401 worksheet) the transfer should then show at the store.

title: PO TYPES
text: By Matt Shepheard Purchase Order/Inventory Transfer Type ===================================== PO Type PurchaseOrder Local Origin = 0 PurchaseOrder HQ Origin = 1 Inventory Transfer Local Origin Receive = 2 Inventory Transfer Local Origin Issue = 3 Inventory Transfer HQ Origin Receive = 4 Inventory Transfer HQ Origin Issue = 5 PO Type refers to column PurchaseOrder.POType at SO and HQ
description:
By Matt Shepheard

 

Purchase Order/Inventory Transfer Type

=====================================

PO Type

PurchaseOrder Local Origin                 =         0

PurchaseOrder HQ Origin                 =        1

Inventory Transfer Local Origin Receive        =        2

Inventory Transfer Local Origin Issue        =        3

Inventory Transfer HQ Origin Receive        =        4

Inventory Transfer HQ Origin Issue        =        5

 

PO Type refers to column PurchaseOrder.POType at SO and HQ

title: RMS POS is not showing on the Screen/Screen keyboard has moved
text: By Abbie Lawton If a customer has logged a case regarding the POS or onscreen keyboard not showing correctly on the screen. This could be a case that the windows position or size is incorrect. One way of changing the size is by using CTRL + F6 where a screen menu will pop up. If CTRL + F6 does not work, you maybe find a screen button on the POS that also allows you to see this menu. In this menu there will be options for changing the transaction screen and an option for the onscreen keyboard. By editing the Position and the Size, you will be able to correct the positions of the POS and one screen keyboard. Once you have made your changes click OK for these to take effect.
description:
By Abbie Lawton

If a customer has logged a case regarding the POS or onscreen keyboard not showing correctly on the screen. This could be a case that the windows position or size is incorrect.

One way of changing the size is by using CTRL + F6 where a screen menu will pop up. If CTRL + F6 does not work, you maybe find a screen button on the POS that also allows you to see this menu.

In this menu there will be options for changing the transaction screen and an option for the onscreen keyboard. By editing the Position and the Size, you will be able to correct the positions of the POS and one screen keyboard. Once you have made your changes click OK for these to take effect.

title: RMS BACKOFFICE POLLING
text: By AL/RC Overview HQ has a process called HQserver running. Each store has a process called HQClient running. The customer sets the frequency of the interaction between the 2 programs. This process updates the HQ with sales, Purchase orders and transfers info from the POS. Then coming the other way are transfers form other stores. PO’s created in BO, new products created and price updates, amongst other things. In most cases this is a few minutes to resolve and has little impact on the business if it is down for a while. In some cases a customer may log the call saying that polling Is not working and we have urgent sale prices that need updating. In a situation like this then the priority would be much higher. As referred to sometimes customers don’t even notice this process has stopped for several weeks or even months. The first indication that there is a problem is the lack of sales data from the store. This is collected by the processing of a data upload worksheet and is the only one that runs automatically with no interaction from the customer. So, if no one is monitoring sales data then it wouldn’t get picked up.
description:
By AL/RC

Overview

HQ has a process called HQserver running.

Each store has a process called HQClient running.

The customer sets the frequency of the interaction between the 2 programs.

This process updates the HQ with sales, Purchase orders and transfers info from the POS.

 

Then coming the other way are transfers form other stores. PO’s created in BO, new products created and price updates, amongst other things.

 

In most cases this is a few minutes to resolve and has little impact on the business if it is down for a while.

In some cases a customer may log the call saying that polling Is not working and we have urgent sale prices that need updating.

In a situation like this then the priority would be much higher. 

 

As referred to sometimes customers don’t even notice this process has stopped for several weeks or even months.

The first indication that there is a problem is the lack of sales data from the store. This is collected  by the processing of a data upload worksheet and is the only one that runs automatically with no interaction from the customer. So, if no one is monitoring sales data then it wouldn’t get picked up.

title: Reindex RMS Database
text: (By JS) Reindexing an RMS database can be done via SQL or Store Ops Administrator SQL Query The below SQL is to be ran against the RMS database. EXEC sp_MSforeachtable @command1="print '?' DBCC DBREINDEX ('?', ' ', 80)" GO EXEC sp_updatestats GO Or Rebuild indexes where fragmentation > 30% declare @frag_Temp as Table ( ID int identity(1,1), [objectid][int] NULL, [indexid][int] NULL, [partitionnum][int] NULL, [frag] [float] NULL ) Declare @Count int Declare @i tinyint=1 DECLARE @schemaname sysname; DECLARE @objectname sysname; DECLARE @indexname sysname; DECLARE @objectid int; DECLARE @indexid int; DECLARE @partitionnum bigint; DECLARE @partitioncount bigint; DECLARE @SQLCommand as Nvarchar(3000) insert into @frag_Temp SELECT object_id AS objectid, index_id AS indexid, partition_number AS partitionnum, avg_fragmentation_in_percent AS frag FROM sys.dm_db_index_physical_stats (DB_ID(), NULL, NULL , NULL, 'LIMITED') --Arguments 1(Database_ID,object_Id,Index_ID,partition,mode WHERE avg_fragmentation_in_percent >=30.0 AND index_id> 0; select @Count=Count(*) from @frag_Temp --Get Total Count While(@i1) SELECT @SQLCommand=@SQLCommand + ' PARTITION=' + convert(Char,@partitionnum); EXEC(@SQLCommand); --Increment Count set @i=@i+1 end
description:
(By JS)

Reindexing an RMS database can be done via SQL or Store Ops Administrator

 

SQL Query 

 

The below SQL is to be ran against the RMS database.

 

EXEC sp_MSforeachtable @command1="print '?' DBCC DBREINDEX ('?', ' ', 80)"

GO

EXEC sp_updatestats

GO 

 

Or 

 

Rebuild indexes where fragmentation > 30%

 

declare @frag_Temp as Table

(

    ID int identity(1,1),

       [objectid][int] NULL,

       [indexid][int] NULL,

       [partitionnum][int] NULL,

       [frag] [float] NULL

)

 

Declare @Count int

Declare @i tinyint=1

DECLARE @schemaname sysname;

DECLARE @objectname sysname;

DECLARE @indexname sysname;

DECLARE @objectid int;

DECLARE @indexid int;

DECLARE @partitionnum bigint;

DECLARE @partitioncount bigint;

DECLARE @SQLCommand as Nvarchar(3000)

insert into @frag_Temp

SELECT

    object_id AS objectid,

    index_id AS indexid,

    partition_number AS partitionnum,

    avg_fragmentation_in_percent AS frag

FROM sys.dm_db_index_physical_stats (DB_ID(), NULL, NULL , NULL, 'LIMITED')

--Arguments 1(Database_ID,object_Id,Index_ID,partition,mode

WHERE avg_fragmentation_in_percent >=30.0 AND index_id> 0;

 

select @Count=Count(*) from @frag_Temp --Get Total Count

       While(@i<=@Count)

          Begin

             select @objectid=objectid,@indexid=indexid,@partitionnum=partitionnum

                from @frag_Temp where ID=@i

 

              --Get tableName and its schema

                 select @objectname=o.name,@schemaname=c.name from

                 sys.objects o

                 inner join  sys.schemas c on o.schema_ID=c.schema_ID

                 where o.object_id=@objectid

               --Get Index Name

                      select @indexname=name

                     from sys.indexes

                     where index_id=@indexid and object_id=@objectid

               --Get Partition Count

               select @partitioncount=count(*) from sys.partitions

                      where object_id=@objectid and index_id=@indexid

      

                SELECT @SQLCommand= 'Alter Index ' + @indexname + ' ON ' + @schemaname + '.' + @objectname + ' REBUILD'  

                      IF(@partitioncount>1)

                      SELECT @SQLCommand=@SQLCommand +  ' PARTITION=' +  convert(Char,@partitionnum);

                     

                   EXEC(@SQLCommand);

 

               --Increment Count

               set @i=@i+1

end

text: (by JS) The following is a download link to the latest RMSify Installer: https://cds.k3retail.com:444/K3RMSify/downloads/RMSify.zip The latest RMSify program files can be found at: https://axk3btg.sharepoint.com/:f:/s/RMSifyShopifySupport/EtfvIWGj3SpMtFDkpNNQKBEBrx_unIZC73OLaXsfyHqBLw?e=4UpUTz RMSify Update Steps To update RMSify follow these steps: Close RMS POS Exit RMSify Automatic Web Orders if open (you can do this by right clicking the globe icon by the clock and selecting 'Exit') Open RMSify Sync by running as admin and sign in Go to Updates > Check for updates Once the update completes and RMSify reopens you can check you are running the correct version (9.0.0.XX) by going to Help > About Reopen RMS POS by running as admin Please note in a Headquarters environment you will need to update your Headquarters first followed by all POS machines for this functionality to work correctly.
description:
(by JS)

The following is a download link to the latest RMSify Installer:

https://cds.k3retail.com:444/K3RMSify/downloads/RMSify.zip

 

The latest RMSify program files can be found at:

https://axk3btg.sharepoint.com/:f:/s/RMSifyShopifySupport/EtfvIWGj3SpMtFDkpNNQKBEBrx_unIZC73OLaXsfyHqBLw?e=4UpUTz

 

RMSify Update Steps

 

To update RMSify follow these steps:

  • Close RMS POS
  • Exit RMSify Automatic Web Orders if open (you can do this by right clicking the globe icon by the clock and selecting 'Exit')
  • Open RMSify Sync by running as admin and sign in
  • Go to Updates > Check for updates
  • Once the update completes and RMSify reopens you can check you are running the correct version (9.0.0.XX) by going to Help > About
  • Reopen RMS POS by running as admin

 

 

Please note in a Headquarters environment you will need to update your Headquarters first followed by all POS machines for this functionality to work correctly.

title: Updating Mailchimp Audience
text: (By TT) CDS • Log on to CDS as admin user go and go to RMSify • On the top filters choose O RMSify Version = RMSify O Status = Active • Copy the resulting table into excel using `Match Destination Formatting` • Remove the unnecessary Monthly Price, Status and blank headed columns • Save the result as a csv Mailchimp • Log in to Mailchimp: • Go to audience -> RMSify Active Customers -> Import contacts • Import the created csv • Modify the existing the existing templates in Brand • Create a new campaign to send the mail shot
description:
(By TT)

CDS

• Log on to CDS as admin user go and go to RMSify

• On the top filters choose

O RMSify Version = RMSify

O Status = Active

• Copy the resulting table into excel using `Match Destination Formatting`

• Remove the unnecessary Monthly Price, Status and blank headed columns

• Save the result as a csv

 

Mailchimp

• Log in to Mailchimp:

• Go to audience -> RMSify Active Customers -> Import contacts

• Import the created csv

• Modify the existing the existing templates in Brand

• Create a new campaign to send the mail shot

title: Stock Counting Guide
text: By Matthew Sheppeard Introduction Stock counting compares the actual stock to the computer stock, it gives an indication of stock lost through inaccurate stock movements and stealing. Stock takes are usually done at least once each year, but can be done more frequently. They can be a done on all the stock, or by individual department, category, supplier or any combination. They must be completed thoroughly and accurately. The secret of accurate stock count is preparation and organisation. Preparation For Stock Count Once the stock count date is decided, it is usually the Branch Managers responsibility to ensure adequate preparation is carried out. This will include. - All garments are ticketed so that the items can be scanned. - All barcode tickets are placed for easy access for quick scanning. - All staff are informed, and know their specific stock count responsibilities. - All stock is easily accessible and spread out wherever possible. Recommended stock count disciplines The shop should be divided into areas e.g. Shop floor, Windows, Displays, Fitting Rooms, Stock Room etc, and ideally a plan drawn up for staff reference (see appendix 1). Each area should be divided into locations and each location should be numbered (see appendix 2). Staff should be divided into teams of two, one person to do a physical count of the location and another to scan all the tickets. Once each location has been counted and scanned, the quantities should be compared for accuracy. Once the team is certain they have an accurate count they can download the scanner gun and move onto the next location. It is advisable to group together all similar items i.e. same colour and size, and stock count them together. The only stock you do not include in the stock count is any stock belonging to a customer e.g. garments being altered or returned items being sent to the manufacture The stock count can begin before the close of business away from the shop floor only e.g. in the stock room. Each counted area must be sealed off after it has been counted, and the shop floor should not be started prior to the close of business. Sequence Of Events for A Full Stock Check It is vital that the computer stock and actual stock are represented at the exact same point in time i.e. if the stock count is carried out on Sunday evening after close of business. The Physical inventory list MUST be created at the exact same time. To ensure an accurate stock count you must follow the correct sequence of events: Back up the current database. Create a stock count list at the close of business on the day of the stock count. Scan each location in the store, comparing the scanner count to a hand count. Download the scanner gun Import the stock count file DO NOT COMMIT Continue scanning each location and downloading the scanner selecting the option to ‘add to the stock count’ Once everything is downloaded and imported but NOT COMMITTED, create an active report detailing the physical count against the computer expected stock and reviewing the Delta (discrepancy) values. This report should be checked for accuracy. Any amendments can be added to or corrected in the stock count. Once you are happy with the stock count set the reason code for the stock amendments and then commit the stock count. BHT Stock Counting Procedures The BHT guns are used for stock counting they are simple to use, but you should ensure that all staff involved in the stock count are familiar with how they work. The BHT guns are battery powered, and it is vital that the batteries are sufficiently charged prior to the stock count. They use AAA batteries. To Check Battery Power Press the oval button underneath the screen and the PWR button together. This shows L (low) to H (high) battery power. IMPORTANT If the batteries need replacing, do not leave the batteries out of the scanner for more than three minutes otherwise you will loose all scanned information and the programme, it will have to be sent to RSG for Reprogramming. To Start Scanning Press the PWR button, this displays the menu: 1. DATA CAPTURE 2. SEND BATCH 3. DELETE BATCH Select 1 DATA CAPTURE, the screen displays: Branch Number This must be 4 numbers e.g. 0001 for branch 1, press ENT button. Action code Input 00 for stock count press ENT button. Loc This is for the location numbers taken from the shop floor plan, input the number and press ENT button. Screen now displays Scan or Key code C: It is now ready to start scanning. Press the oval button underneath the screen and 'dab' the barcode with the scanner. The scanner will bleep when it accepts the barcode and assumes a quantity of 1. Scan all the items in the location. If a barcode will not scan, it is possible to input the barcode then press the ENT button. To display a subtotal To display a subtotal of the garments in the scanner gun press ENT button, then the full stop '.' button. The scanner will display ‘WORKING !!!’. The total quantity scanned in this location is displayed, underneath this is the total quantity scanned into the gun (the gun will hold about 4000 barcodes before it is full). To only view the current location quantity press F4, this improves the speed of the gun when displaying the count. Record the total for the location onto the stock count sheet against the location number. Now count the garments and reconcile against the BHT scanner count. To Change Location To change the location number press ENT button to accept the last item scanned. Press the F7 button, the screen displays: Loc Input next fixture number and press ENT button. Screen now displays C: and is ready to start scanning the next location. After the location is scanned, record scanner subtotal onto stock count sheet and reconcile with hand count. To Correct Incorrectly Scanned Locations If the BHT scanner total is LESS than hand counted total. Press F5 button repeatedly. This scrolls backwards through the scanned garments. Compare the barcode with the barcode number displayed on the scanner screen to determine which garment was missed. Press F6 button repeatedly. This scrolls forwards through scanned garments, until screen displays C: Scan missed item and re check the scanner subtotal. Scanner total is MORE than hand counted total. Press F5 button repeatedly, scrolling backwards through the scanned garments. Compare the barcodes with the barcode number displayed on scanner screen to determine which garment has been scanned twice. At the wrongly scanned barcode, press the CLR button. This clears the quantity, now press 0 to record a quantity of zero, press the ENT button. Press F6 to scroll forwards through the scanned items until the screen displays C:, re check the scanner subtotal. Once the stock count is complete, press the F1 button until the menu is displayed. Press the PWR button to switch scanner off. NOTE: If scanner is left unattended for more than one minute it switches off automatically to save battery power. It will not record the last garment scanned unless you pressed the ENT button after the last item scanned and screen was displaying C: To Delete BHT Scanner Information IMPORTANT Do not delete the scanner information until it has been downloaded into the computer.. Switch on the BHT by pressing the PWR button, the menu will be displayed (if it is not press F1 button until menu is displayed). Select 3 Delete Batch the screen displays: DELETE BATCH F3=yes F4=no Press F3 button, the screen displays BATCH DELETED OK Switch the power off. ERROR MESSAGES Error 6 If the error message is displayed the BHT scanner will freeze, it occurs when the item scanned is accepted as a quantity. You should phone RSG Helpdesk who will talk you through the procedure to clear it. Return to personnel in charge This message appears when the gun has lost all its information including the programme. This happens when the power to the gun is missing for more than 3 minutes e.g. if the batteries are left out too long. The gun must be reprogrammed by returning it to RSG, and the stock count must be done again. RSG Helpdesk Tel: 0121 742 0485 BHT Download Procedures To Prepare BHT for Download The BHT scanner should be returned to the menu after use, to check this switch the BHT gun on by pressing the PWR button. Press the F1 button until the menu is displayed. Switch the power off. Connect the BHT scanner to the computer via the cable. Ensure connection cable is pushed in hard. The BHT scanner is now ready to download, now turn to the computer. To Prepare the Computer to Download From the desk top, click on the BHT download icon, the screen displays Filename Input the name of the file this can be structured as e.g.ST for stock take, DDMM day and month, NN the gun download number, or called e.g. ‘window display’. On BHT Scanner Switch on the power by pressing the PWR button. The menu is displayed, select: 2: SEND BATCH F3 = yes F4 = no Press F3 to send the stock count information from the BHT scanner to the computer. The screen displays, SENDING BATCH 0000/NNNN Return to the computer. On The Computer Click on Start Receive The numbers on the BHT scanner screen will scroll upwards, and once the download has finished the scanner will bleep twice. The BHT screen displays: BATCH SENT OK Delete Batch F3 = Yes F4 = No DO NOT DELETE THE BATCH Press the F4 for No and the scanner will return to the menu. Turn BHT scanner off. By pressing the PWR button. Repeat this process for each BHT Scanner Gun used, allocating a separate name or number each time. Back up the current database. From Store Operation Manager select, Utilities, Back up Database Back up the database as e.g. PrestockcountDDMMYYYY.bck To Create a Physical Inventory File. At the close of business on the day of the stock count, you must create a stock count file. This will be used to compare the physical count to the computer stock. From the Store Operations Manager select, Inventory, Physical Inventory, New, the screen displays the selection options for the stock counted items. For a full stock count select to Generate for all items in the selected Group, and select All items. The screen displays the Physical Inventory Count, which is a list of all items selected. Complete the stock count reference number and description. Ref. Number This is your reference for the stock count, if this field is left blank, the system will allocate a sequential reference number. Description e.g. opening stock count Click OK. This has created a file holding the computer stock at the moment of creation, and ideally should be completed at the close of business on the day of the stock count. You must now use the scanners to count the physical stock, and download the files onto the computer (see page 4) To Import the stock count file Once you have counted the stock and downloaded the scanner gun, each downloaded file must be imported into the Physical Inventory Count file to create the comparison report, once this report is reviewed and audited as necessary the stock count is committed onto the system. Open Store operations Manager, Inventory, Physical inventory Click on the physical inventory file created for this stock count. Once it is opened click on import file, click Next. File to Import browse for downloaded stock count file. This is usually located in C:\program Files\Microsoft Retail Management systems\Store Operations\Custom\Stock Takes Files of type: change to Comma delimited files (*.CSV) File name: select the relevant file from a list of stock count files previously downloaded Click open File type Character delimited (TAB,CSV) Click Next. Check the screen is set as above and click Next Now define how the imported items will affect the rest of the counted stock. Items: Update matching items only This will only recognise matching items i.e. if an item from another department or category (according to the filter specified) is scanned in error it will ignore it. Update matching items and add new items This will include any items scanned outside the selected filter, and will adjust their values too. Quantities: Add to existing counts Where more than one gun has been downloaded, this will add the quantities of a matching item together. This is the usual setting if all stock is distributed around the store and appears in more than one location. Replace existing counts Where more than one gun has been downloaded, this will replace the original quantity of a matching item. This is the usual setting if the stock items have been grouped together before counting, and all similar items are included in this count. Click Next. . The file for import is now displayed on the screen. Select Import. The screen displays the Physical Inventory Count and includes the imported file in the Counted column. This import procedure must be completed for every downloaded stock count file used. Auditing the Stock Count After importing all the stock count files, the Physical Inventory file is used to create a discrepancy report and audit the stock count. The quantities scanned now appear next to each item in the counted column. Select Calculate. The screen now displays the delta (discrepancy) value between the physical count and the computer stock. At this point the stock count can be committed to change the computer stock, however, it is recommended that the result of the stock count is printed and audited prior to commitment. If you wish to see ALL items untick Hide items with no discrepancies From the screen select Print. The filter screen is displayed. Only the current Physical Inventory file is selected, click OK. The screen displays the full stock count results. This active report can be manipulated to display items by supplier, department or category. The report should be printed and used to audit the stock count. Sorting the report data After you generate a report, you can then sort the data directly on the report preview screen. Dragging columns Use your mouse to adjust or move the columns. For example if your data is easier viewed by category click and drag the category column to the left hand side of the report. Grouping data You can also group the report data in any way you want. After you generate the report, click the Select Columns to Group button on the Store Operations Report toolbar. Use the drop-down list box to specify the columns whose data you want to group. Choose from grouping no data to grouping several columns. Expanding or collapsing data Store Operations includes an additional sorting tool that lets you customize your report. For example, you may not want to see all the categories for a particular department. However, you may still want that same report to display specific information for another department. Store Operations enables you to pick and choose whatever data you want your reports to show. There are two ways you can expand (show) or collapse (hide) report data: Using the toolbar - Use the toolbar buttons to quickly expand/collapse all the report data at once. Click the Expand All button to display all the report data, or click the Collapse All button to hide detailed report data. Individually adjusting each group of items - Expand/collapse individual components. Each column contains a series of groupings. In the front of each group of data is a plus sign (+). To expand the group and see the data, click the plus sign (+). If you want to contract the grouping, click the minus sign (-). Changing data order By clicking the mouse over the columns you can change the sort order. When you sort by text fields (i.e., items, etc.), entries are displayed in alphabetical order (A-Z or Z-A) based on the contents of the selected field. Likewise, value fields (i.e., total sales, number of visits, etc.) are sorted into numeric order (0-100 or 0-100) and date fields are sorted into chronological order (1/1/01-12/31/01 or 12/31/01-1/1/01). In order to sort entries in a column, click on its heading. Repeatedly clicking on the header will toggle between ascending and descending sorting. Adjusting header and columns Store Operations gives you the flexibility to organize your data directly on the print preview screen. After you generate a report, you can adjust the header. To hide/unhide the header, go to the Store Operations Report toolbar and click the Hide/Unhide Report Header button. Adding and removing Columns You can adjust your report's columns in a couple ways. First, choose what columns you want to display or hide e.g. you may not want the bin location displayed on the report. After you generate this report, right-click your mouse and select Hide/Unhide Columns. You will then see the Options window where you can select or clear the appropriate column checkboxes. Memorizing report settings Store Operations lets you memorize (save) your report settings so that you can quickly generate the same report with the same exact settings. The memorized report(s) option will not appear in the Reports menu until you have memorized at least one report format. Once you memorize a report, you can locate it in the Reports menu. To memorize the selected report On the report preview screen, click the Memorize button. On the Memorize Report window, enter the report name by which the report may be recalled. Click Memorize. 3. When you see a window that tells you the report has been memorized, click OK. Tip: To generate the memorized report, go to the Reports menu, click Memorized, and then click the desired report. To Commit the Stock Count Once you are happy with the stock counted on the Physical inventory file the stock values must be committed. First Set the reason codes for the stock count from the reason codes list. Select Commit

To ensure an accurate stock count you must follow the correct sequence of events:

                                                       

    • Back up the current database.
    • Create a stock count list at the close of business on the day of the stock count.
    • Scan each location in the store, comparing the scanner count to a hand count. 
    • Download the scanner gun 
    • Import the stock count file DO NOT COMMIT
    • Continue scanning each location and downloading the scanner selecting the option to ‘add to the stock count’
    • Once everything is downloaded and imported but NOT COMMITTED, create an active report detailing the physical count against the computer expected stock and reviewing the Delta (discrepancy) values. This report should be checked for accuracy. Any amendments can be added to or corrected in the stock count.
    • Once you are happy with the stock count set the reason code for the stock amendments and then commit the stock count.

The BHT guns are used for stock counting they are simple to use, but you should ensure that all staff involved in the stock count are familiar with how they work.

 

The BHT guns are battery powered, and it is vital that the batteries are sufficiently charged prior to the stock count. They use AAA batteries.

 

To Check Battery Power

Press the oval button underneath the screen and the PWR button together. This shows L (low) to H (high) battery power.

 

IMPORTANT

If the batteries need replacing, do not leave the batteries out of the scanner for more than three minutes otherwise you will loose all scanned information and the programme, it will have to be sent to RSG for

Reprogramming.

 

To Start Scanning      

Press the PWR button, this displays the menu:

 

        1. DATA CAPTURE

        3. DELETE BATCH

  

Select 1 DATA CAPTURE, the screen displays:

Branch Number 

This must be 4 numbers e.g. 0001 for branch 1, press ENT button.

Action code

Input 00 for stock count press ENT button.

Loc

This is for the location numbers taken from the shop floor plan, input the number and press ENT button.

 

Screen now displays 

Scan or Key code

C:

It is now ready to start scanning. Press the oval button underneath the screen and 'dab' the barcode with the scanner. The scanner will bleep when it accepts the barcode and assumes a quantity of 1. Scan all the items in the location.

If a barcode will not scan, it is possible to input the barcode then press the ENT button.

 

 

To display a subtotal

To display a subtotal of the garments in the scanner gun press ENT button, then the full stop '.' button. The scanner will display   ‘WORKING !!!’. The total quantity scanned in this location is displayed, underneath this is the total quantity scanned into the gun (the gun will hold about 4000 barcodes before it is full).  

To only view the current location quantity press F4, this improves the speed of the gun when displaying the count. Record the total for the location onto the stock count sheet against the location number. Now count the garments and reconcile against the BHT scanner count.                      

 

 

 

To Change Location 

To change the location number press ENT button to accept the last item scanned. Press the F7 button, the screen displays:

Loc 

Input next fixture number and press ENT button.          

 

Screen now displays C: and is ready to start scanning the next location.  After the location is scanned, record scanner subtotal onto stock count sheet and reconcile with hand count. 

 

 

To Correct Incorrectly Scanned Locations

If the BHT scanner total is LESS than hand counted total.

Press F5 button repeatedly. This scrolls backwards through the scanned garments. Compare the barcode with the barcode number displayed on the scanner screen to determine which garment was missed.                          

Press F6 button repeatedly. This scrolls forwards through scanned garments, until screen displays C:                    

Scan missed item and re check the scanner subtotal.

 

Scanner total is MORE than hand counted total.

Press F5 button repeatedly, scrolling backwards through the scanned garments. Compare the barcodes with the barcode number displayed on scanner screen to determine which garment has been scanned twice.

At the wrongly scanned barcode, press the CLR button. This clears the quantity, now press 0 to record a quantity of zero, press the ENT button.                          

Press F6 to scroll forwards through the scanned items until the screen displays C:, re check the scanner subtotal.

                                               

Once the stock count is complete, press the F1 button until the menu is displayed. Press the PWR button to switch scanner off.                          

 

NOTE: 

If scanner is left unattended for more than one minute it switches off automatically to save battery power. It will not record the last garment scanned unless you pressed the ENT button after the last item scanned and screen was displaying C:                                                                                    

 

To Delete BHT Scanner Information

IMPORTANT

Do not delete the scanner information until it has been downloaded into the computer..

 

Switch on the BHT by pressing the PWR button, the menu will be displayed (if it is not press F1 button until menu is displayed). Select 3 Delete Batch the screen displays:

DELETE BATCH F3=yes F4=no 

Press F3 button, the screen displays

BATCH DELETED OK      

Switch the power off.

 

ERROR MESSAGES

Error  6

If the error message is displayed the BHT scanner will freeze, it occurs when the item scanned is accepted as a quantity. You should phone RSG Helpdesk who will talk you through the procedure to clear it.

 

Return to personnel in charge

This message appears when the gun has lost all its information including the programme. This happens when the power to the gun is missing for more than 3 minutes e.g. if the batteries are left out too long.

The gun must be reprogrammed by returning it to RSG, and the stock count must be done again.

 

RSG Helpdesk Tel: 0121 742 0485              

 

BHT Download Procedures

 

To Prepare BHT for Download    

The BHT scanner should be returned to the menu after use, to check this switch the BHT gun on by pressing the PWR button. Press the F1 button until the menu is displayed. Switch the power off. 

Connect the BHT scanner to the computer via the cable. Ensure connection cable is pushed in hard.

The BHT scanner is now ready to download, now turn to the computer.

 

To Prepare the Computer to Download   

From the desk top, click on the BHT download icon, the screen displays

 

 

 

Filename    Input the name of the file this can be structured as e.g.ST for stock take, DDMM day and month, NN the gun download number, or called e.g. ‘window display’.

 

On BHT Scanner    

Switch on the power by pressing the PWR button. The menu is displayed, select:

2: SEND BATCH                       

F3 = yes F4 = no  

Press F3 to send the stock count information from the BHT scanner to the computer. The screen displays,

SENDING BATCH  0000/NNNN

Return to the computer.

 

On The Computer        

Click on Start Receive

The numbers on the BHT scanner screen will scroll upwards, and once the download has finished the scanner will bleep twice.

The BHT screen displays:             

BATCH SENT OK  

Delete Batch F3 = Yes F4 = No 

DO NOT DELETE THE BATCH Press the F4 for No and the scanner will return to the menu. Turn BHT scanner off. By pressing the PWR button.       

 

Repeat this process for each BHT Scanner Gun used, allocating a separate name or number each time.

 

 

 

 

Back up the current database.

From Store Operation Manager select, 

Utilities, 

Back up Database

 

 

Back up the database as e.g. PrestockcountDDMMYYYY.bck

 

 

 

 

To Create a Physical Inventory File.

At the close of business on the day of the stock count, you must create a stock count file. This will be used to compare the physical count to the computer stock.

From the Store Operations Manager select, 

Inventory, 

Physical Inventory, 

New, the screen displays the selection options for the stock counted items.

 

 

For a full stock count select to Generate for all items in the selected Group, and select All items.

 

 

 

The screen displays the Physical Inventory Count, which is a list of all items selected. Complete the stock count reference number and description.

 

 

 

Ref. Number    This is your reference for the stock count, if this field is left blank, the system will allocate a sequential reference number.

Description    e.g. opening stock count 

 

Click OK. This has created a file holding the computer stock at the moment of creation, and ideally should be completed at the close of business on the day of the stock count. 

 

You must now use the scanners to count the physical stock, and download the files onto the computer (see page 4)

 

To Import the stock count file 

Once you have counted the stock and downloaded the scanner gun, each downloaded file must be imported into the Physical Inventory Count file to create the comparison report, once this report is reviewed and audited as necessary the stock count is committed onto the system. 

Open Store operations Manager, 

Inventory, 

Physical inventory 

Click on the physical inventory file created for this stock count. Once it is opened click on import file, click Next.

 

 

 

File to Import     browse for downloaded stock count file. This is usually located in 

C:\program Files\Microsoft Retail Management systems\Store Operations\Custom\Stock Takes

Files of type:     change to Comma delimited files (*.CSV)

File name:    select the relevant file from a list of stock count files previously downloaded

Click open

 

File type    Character delimited (TAB,CSV)

Click Next.

 

 

 

Check the screen is set as above and click Next

 

 

Now define how the imported items will affect the rest of the counted stock.

 

 

 

Items:

Update matching items only    This will only recognise matching items i.e. if an item from another department or category (according to the filter specified) is scanned in error it will ignore it.

Update matching items and add new items    This will include any items scanned outside the selected filter, and will adjust their values too.        

 

Quantities:

Add to existing counts    Where more than one gun has been downloaded, this will add the quantities of a matching item together. This is the usual setting if all stock is distributed around the store and appears in more than one location.

Replace existing counts    Where more than one gun has been downloaded, this will replace the original quantity of a matching item. This is the usual setting if the stock items have been grouped together before counting, and all similar items are included in this count.

Click Next.

 

.

    

The file for import is now displayed on the screen. Select Import.

The screen displays the Physical Inventory Count and includes the imported file in the Counted column.

 

This import procedure must be completed for every downloaded stock count file used.

 

 

 

Auditing the Stock Count

After importing all the stock count files, the Physical Inventory file is used to create a discrepancy report and audit the stock count. The quantities scanned now appear next to each item in the counted column. Select Calculate. 

 

 

 

The screen now displays the delta  (discrepancy) value between the physical count and the computer stock. At this point the stock count can be committed to change the computer stock, however, it is recommended that the result of the stock count is printed and audited prior to commitment. 

 

If you wish to see ALL items untick Hide items with no discrepancies

 

From the screen select Print. The filter screen is displayed. Only the current Physical Inventory file is selected, click OK. The screen displays the full stock count results. This active report can be manipulated to display items by supplier, department or category. The report should be printed and used to audit the stock count.

 

 

 

Sorting the report data

After you generate a report, you can then sort the data directly on the report preview screen.

 

Dragging columns

Use your mouse to adjust or move the columns. For example if your data is easier viewed by category click and drag the category column to the left hand side of the report. 

 

Grouping data

You can also group the report data in any way you want. After you generate the report, click the Select Columns to Group button on the Store Operations Report toolbar. Use the drop-down list box to specify the columns whose data you want to group. Choose from grouping no data to grouping several columns.

 

Expanding or collapsing data

Store Operations includes an additional sorting tool that lets you customize your report. For example, you may not want to see all the categories for a particular department. However, you may still want that same report to display specific information for another department. Store Operations enables you to pick and choose whatever data you want your reports to show.

There are two ways you can expand (show) or collapse (hide) report data:

Using the toolbar - Use the toolbar buttons to quickly expand/collapse all the report data at once. Click the Expand All button to display all the report data, or click the Collapse All button to hide detailed report data.

Individually adjusting each group of items - Expand/collapse individual components. Each column contains a series of groupings. In the front of each group of data is a plus sign (+). To expand the group and see the data, click the plus sign (+). If you want to contract the grouping, click the minus sign (-).

 

Changing data order

By clicking the mouse over the columns you can change the sort order. When you sort by text fields (i.e., items, etc.), entries are displayed in alphabetical order (A-Z or Z-A) based on the contents of the selected field. Likewise, value fields (i.e., total sales, number of visits, etc.) are sorted into numeric order (0-100 or 0-100) and date fields are sorted into chronological order (1/1/01-12/31/01 or 12/31/01-1/1/01).

In order to sort entries in a column, click on its heading. Repeatedly clicking on the header will toggle between ascending and descending sorting. 

 

Adjusting header and columns

Store Operations gives you the flexibility to organize your data directly on the print preview screen. After you generate a report, you can adjust the header. To hide/unhide the header, go to the Store Operations Report toolbar and click the Hide/Unhide Report Header button.

 

Adding and removing Columns

You can adjust your report's columns in a couple ways. First, choose what columns you want to display or hide e.g. you may not want the bin location displayed on the report. After you generate this report, right-click your mouse and select Hide/Unhide Columns. You will then see the Options window where you can select or clear the appropriate column checkboxes. 

 

Memorizing report settings

Store Operations lets you memorize (save) your report settings so that you can quickly generate the same report with the same exact settings. The memorized report(s) option will not appear in the Reports menu until you have memorized at least one report format. Once you memorize a report, you can locate it in the Reports menu.

To memorize the selected report

    • On the report preview screen, click the Memorize button.
    • On the Memorize Report window, enter the report name by which the report may be recalled. Click 

Memorize.

3.       When you see a window that tells you the report has been memorized, click OK.

 

Tip: To generate the memorized report, go to the Reports menu, click Memorized, and then click the desired report. 

 

 

 

To Commit the Stock Count

Once you are happy with the stock counted on the Physical inventory file the stock values must be committed. First 

Set the reason codes for the stock count from the reason codes list. Select Commit

title: BHT 900 Quick Reference Guide
text: (By MS) FUNCTION KEYS: F1 – Takes you back to main menu options (1,2,3). F2 – Item search for a product code number. F3 – N/A F4 - Current Location number and quantity. F5 – Viewing Mode (Back through the scanned list). F6 - Viewing Mode (Forward through the scanned list). F7 – Change Location number. F8 – N/A M1 – [Press for 3 seconds] Control panel for back light, power save, volume and vibrate mode. BS/C – Changes the branch number, location and action code whilst in the middle of a data batch. BS/C – Clears the current screen INPUT data. SF – Shift key for accessing other additional functions. ENT – Enter or Accept button, confirms acceptance of an input quantity or data. . – (Full stop) This will give you a working total of transactions/items. SCAN [+ 2 red buttons on the side] – Scans the barcode. Numbers 0-9 – Inputting quantities or branch numbers etc. _ scan or key code – System ready to Scan BATTERY POWER: The battery power is shown on the main screen. You can also hold down the SF and ENT buttons together to display the battery power status. NOTE: It is useful to have spare batteries, as the guns will only save the data for several minutes whilst you replace the batteries! Always keep spare batteries handy. BHT 900 terminals use 2 x AA batteries. Operational Mode: To Clear the gun of all old transactions or test scans etc: Go to the front menu and choose option 3 – Delete Batch. You can still cancel this request by pressing F4 (no) or continue to delete by pressing F3 (Yes). Warning: This will clear the gun completely of all data. It will be lost forever! To Set the Gun up for a stock-take: Ensure the gun is empty of all data (se note above). Choose option 1 – Data capture, enter branch number. E.g. branch 1 would be 0001 or branch 2 would be 0002 and press enter. Now input the Action code for stocktaking of 00 (Zero-Zero) and enter. Finally input a location number if required (note if you are not using a location numbering system you still have to enter a number – any number will do) and press enter. At this point you will now have a _: prompt on the display. You are now ready to scan a barcode. To Scan a Barcode: Whilst the display shows a _: press SCAN or one of the red buttons on the side, pointing the front of the gun at the barcode. A successful scan will be noted by a bleep from the gun.[or vibration if enabled] The enter/accept button does not need to be pressed if there are more items to be scanned as the gun automatically accepts the previously scanned item with a quantity of 1. Only on the very last item scanned do you need to press enter to accept the last item with a quantity of 1. To input a quantity against a scan: If there is more than one item with the same barcode you can scan one and manually enter the quantity using the key/number pad. After inputting the new quantity you must press enter to accept the new quantity. To check a locations number count: Press F4. If you to continue in this location press F4 again. If you wish to change location and start a new one press F7 twice. To check what has been scanned: Press F5 to scroll back through the list and also F6 to move forward through the list. To continue scanning you must press F6 until you reach the _: prompt again. To make a correction to a quantity: Press F5 to scroll back to the item to change. At the item press BS/C [hold for 2 seconds] to clear the quantity, then enter the new quantity accordingly. If the item needs to be removed completely then enter 0 (Zero) and this item will not be counted. To download the guns information to the computer: Go back to the main menu and choose option 2 – Send Batch. Answer F3 or F4 accordingly. Meanwhile you should have the data cable connected to the BHT Gun. From the desktop menu choose the BHT download icon for BHT 900. Enter a name for the file (Suggest DDMMYYnn where nn is a sequential number referring to the number of downloads for the day or session. 19030801). Then Choose START. The data should start to download and this should be visible on screen. Watch out for Errors, If there are any, this will be shown on screen. Suggest you print the errors and resolve before continuing, When finished, detach the gun from the cable. Ensure Guns are emptied of data before starting a new batch, However this should not be done until you are sure the batch has been successfully downloaded. NOTE: The gun automatically switches itself off if no keys have been pressed for a duration of 30 seconds or more. If the screen is blank when you pick the gun up or goes off whilst holding it, don’t panic, just press the button to restore the screen again. This is a safety device to stop the display being damaged by the image on the display.
description:
(By MS)

FUNCTION KEYS:

F1 – Takes you back to main menu options (1,2,3).

F2 – Item search for a product code number.

F3 – N/A

F4 - Current Location number and quantity.

F5 – Viewing Mode (Back through the scanned list).

F6 - Viewing Mode (Forward through the scanned list).

F7 – Change Location number.

F8 – N/A

M1 – [Press for 3 seconds] Control panel for back light,

power save, volume and vibrate mode.

 

BS/C – Changes the branch number, location and action

code whilst in the middle of a data batch.

BS/C – Clears the current screen INPUT data.

SF – Shift key for accessing other additional functions.

ENT – Enter or Accept button, confirms acceptance of an

input quantity or data.

. – (Full stop) This will give you a working total of transactions/items.

SCAN [+ 2 red buttons on the side] – Scans the barcode.

Numbers 0-9 – Inputting quantities or branch numbers etc.

_ scan or key code – System ready to Scan

 

BATTERY POWER: The battery power is shown on the main screen. You can also

hold down the SF and ENT buttons together to display the battery power status.

NOTE: It is useful to have spare batteries, as the guns will only save the data for

several minutes whilst you replace the batteries! Always keep spare batteries handy.

BHT 900 terminals use 2 x AA batteries.

 

Operational Mode:

 

To Clear the gun of all old transactions or test scans etc:

 

Go to the front menu and choose option 3 – Delete Batch. You can still cancel this

request by pressing F4 (no) or continue to delete by pressing F3 (Yes). Warning:

This will clear the gun completely of all data. It will be lost forever!

 

To Set the Gun up for a stock-take:

 

Ensure the gun is empty of all data (se note above). Choose option 1 – Data

capture, enter branch number. E.g. branch 1 would be 0001 or branch 2 would be

0002 and press enter. Now input the Action code for stocktaking of 00 (Zero-Zero)

and enter. Finally input a location number if required (note if you are not using a

location numbering system you still have to enter a number – any number will do)

and press enter. At this point you will now have a _: prompt on the display. You are

now ready to scan a barcode.

 

To Scan a Barcode:

 

Whilst the display shows a _: press SCAN or one of the red buttons on the side,

pointing the front of the gun at the barcode. A successful scan will be noted by a

bleep from the gun.[or vibration if enabled] The enter/accept button does not need to

be pressed if there are more items to be scanned as the gun automatically accepts

the previously scanned item with a quantity of 1. Only on the very last item scanned

do you need to press enter to accept the last item with a quantity of 1.

 

To input a quantity against a scan:

 

If there is more than one item with the same barcode you can scan one and manually

enter the quantity using the key/number pad. After inputting the new quantity you

must press enter to accept the new quantity.

 

To check a locations number count:

 

Press F4. If you to continue in this location press F4 again. If you wish to change

location and start a new one press F7 twice.

 

To check what has been scanned:

 

Press F5 to scroll back through the list and also F6 to move forward through the list.

To continue scanning you must press F6 until you reach the _: prompt again.

 

To make a correction to a quantity:

 

Press F5 to scroll back to the item to change. At the item press BS/C [hold for 2

seconds] to clear the quantity, then enter the new quantity accordingly. If the item

needs to be removed completely then enter 0 (Zero) and this item will not be

counted.

 

To download the guns information to the computer:

 

Go back to the main menu and choose option 2 – Send Batch. Answer F3 or F4

accordingly. Meanwhile you should have the data cable connected to the BHT Gun.

From the desktop menu choose the BHT download icon for BHT 900. Enter a name

for the file (Suggest DDMMYYnn where nn is a sequential number referring to the

number of downloads for the day or session. 19030801). Then Choose START. The

data should start to download and this should be visible on screen.

Watch out for Errors, If there are any, this will be shown on screen. Suggest you

print the errors and resolve before continuing, When finished, detach the gun from

the cable. Ensure Guns are emptied of data before starting a new batch, However

this should not be done until you are sure the batch has been successfully

downloaded.

 

NOTE: The gun automatically switches itself off if no keys have been pressed for a

duration of 30 seconds or more. If the screen is blank when you pick the gun up or

goes off whilst holding it, don’t panic, just press the button to restore the screen

again. This is a safety device to stop the display being damaged by the image on the

display.

title: Invalid object name  '#Temp' HQ Manager login
text: This error happens when the user opens HQ manager and the worksheet status page appears after logging in. There are a few things that can be attempted as a fix for this issue which are. - Reindex the HQ database using the 'Reindex database' script from another article or using HQ Admin after connecting to the DB. - Delete all of the RMS related temp files in the folder location %temp% on both the local machine and the HQ DB machine - This also can be caused by a slow network connection as it's fails to run the query to bring back the data from the worksheets table which causes the temp table not to exist in the HQ DB.
description:
This error happens when the user opens HQ manager and the worksheet status page appears after logging in. 




There are a few things that can be attempted as a fix for this issue which are.


- Reindex the HQ database using the 'Reindex database' script from another article or using HQ Admin after connecting to the DB.


- Delete all of the RMS related temp files in the folder location %temp% on both the local machine and the HQ DB machine


- This also can be caused by a slow network connection as it's fails to run the query to bring back the data from the worksheets table which causes the temp table not to exist in the HQ DB.

title: Creating a Linked Server for RMS Offline Database usage
text: This SQL query is used for creating a Linked Server in SQL against the local SQL instance for the tills that will be using the offline database. The linked server allows all of the offline transactions and data to be synced across to the live main database once the till has been z read at the end of the day after trading in offline mode. Please ensure you follow the instructions below in the query and fill the information in correctly. This query needs to be ran against the local SQL instance of the till and not the main database machine. Use Master IF NOT EXISTS (select srvname from master.dbo.sysservers where srvname = 'rmsLinkedServer') BEGIN EXEC sp_addlinkedserver 'rmsLinkedServer', '', 'SQLNCLI', NULL, NULL, 'DRIVER={SQL Server};SERVER=SERVER\RMS;UID=sa;PWD=Password;' -- Change SERVER\RMS to remote db server address and update PWD to the sa password. EXEC sp_addlinkedsrvlogin 'rmsLinkedServer' , 'FALSE', NULL, 'User', 'Password'; --Change 'user' to remote server sql username IE 'sa', 'Password' to that users password END
description:
This SQL query is used for creating a Linked Server in SQL against the local SQL instance for the tills that will be using the offline database.


The linked server allows all of the offline transactions and data to be synced across to the live main database once the till has been z read at the end of the day after trading in offline mode.


Please ensure you follow the instructions below in the query and fill the information in correctly. This query needs to be ran against the local SQL instance of the till and not the main database machine.


Use Master

IF NOT EXISTS (select srvname from master.dbo.sysservers where srvname = 'rmsLinkedServer') 

BEGIN

EXEC sp_addlinkedserver 'rmsLinkedServer', '', 'SQLNCLI', NULL, NULL, 'DRIVER={SQL Server};SERVER=SERVER\RMS;UID=sa;PWD=Password;' -- Change SERVER\RMS to remote db server address and update PWD to the sa password.

EXEC sp_addlinkedsrvlogin 'rmsLinkedServer' , 'FALSE', NULL, 'User', 'Password'; --Change 'user' to remote server sql username IE 'sa', 'Password' to that users password

END

title: Windows Mobile Scanners
text: Windows mobile scanners / Dolphin scanners are hardware devices used by RMS RTL customers to perform stocktakes and use with RTL POS Utilities. The devices are running Windows and you can access them remotely by being on the machine it's connected to via teamviewer and then installing / running software on the PC called 'Pocket Controller'. The scanners need to have the K3 Mobile Solution program installed to allow the customers to perform stocktakes. The program is installed as a .cab file and needs to be added to the device via Windows File Explorer on the PC the scanner is connected to. There are full guides inside the Win releases channel.
description:
Windows mobile scanners / Dolphin scanners are hardware devices used by RMS RTL customers to perform stocktakes and use with RTL POS Utilities. 


The devices are running Windows and you can access them remotely by being on the machine it's connected to via teamviewer and then installing / running software on the PC called 'Pocket Controller'. 


The scanners need to have the K3 Mobile Solution program installed to allow the customers to perform stocktakes. The program is installed as a .cab file and needs to be added to the device via Windows File Explorer on the PC the scanner is connected to. 


There are full guides inside the Win releases channel.
